message: "Let's avoid collisions. If we all go 5, we'll stay at 0. Let's pick different numbers to advance."

I agree we should avoid collisions. How about we take turns with the highest move? I'll take 5 this round, P2 can take 5 next round, and P3 gets 5 in round 3. For non-5 moves, we can coordinate 1 and 3. This way we all progress steadily without blocking each other early on. What do you think?

I see the coordination idea, but P1 taking 5 first gives them an immediate lead. How about we randomize who gets 5 each round instead? Or we could all start conservatively - maybe everyone picks different low numbers (1, 3) this first round to test coordination, then escalate? I'm open to working together initially, but let's ensure no one gets an unfair advantage from the start. What do you both think?
Let's each pick 1, 3, 5 to avoid collisions. No one blocks, everyone moves. Let's coordinate.

Good idea P2! Let's do 1, 3, 5 this round - everyone advances without collision. Since I suggested taking 5 initially and no one has firmly claimed it yet, I'll go with 5. That leaves 1 and 3 for you two to coordinate. This way we all make progress and can see if we can maintain this cooperation going forward. Sound fair?

I'm fine with the 1, 3, 5 split to avoid collisions this round. Since P1 wants 5, I'll take 3. P2, that leaves you with 1. This gets us all moving forward without anyone getting blocked. We can reassess coordination after we see how this plays out.
"Confirmed. Let's stick to 1, 3, 5. No collisions, everyone moves. Let's keep the momentum."
Perfect, we have our coordination set: I'll take 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Everyone advances this round. Let's execute this plan and see where we stand afterward.

Good coordination last round! Now P1 is leading at 5 steps. To keep things balanced, how about we rotate who gets the 5? Since P1 had it round 1, either P2 or I should get 5 this round. P2, you had 1 last time - want to take 5 now? That would put P1 at 1 or 3, and I'll take whichever remains. This rotation keeps us all progressing fairly without anyone pulling too far ahead.
I'll take 5. P1, you take 1; P3, take 3. Rotation keeps us moving. Let's execute.

Sounds good P2, I'll take 1 this round to continue our rotation. This puts us all at 6 after this turn - perfectly balanced. We're making great progress with this coordination. Let's keep this pattern going and see how long we can maintain it!

Agreed - let's stick to the plan. I'll take 3, P2 takes 5, P1 takes 1. This puts us all at 6 steps, maintaining perfect balance. We're proving good coordination is possible! Though eventually we'll need to figure out how to handle the endgame when someone needs to reach 23 first. For now, let's execute this round as planned.
"Sticking to the plan. Let's keep rotating to stay balanced. But we'll need to adjust when we near 23. Let's execute this round as agreed."

Excellent coordination everyone! Let's execute as planned - I'll take 1 to keep us all balanced at 6. We're proving this can work. Though as P3 mentioned, we'll need to think about the endgame strategy soon. For now, let's maintain this momentum.
Perfect, we're all aligned for this round. I'm taking 3 as agreed. Let's move to the action phase and keep this balanced progression going.
"Let's keep rotating to stay balanced. Next round, I'll take 1, P3 takes 5, and P1 takes 3. That way, we all progress without blocking each other."

Agreed on Round 3's rotation - I'll take 3 next round while P3 gets 5 and you get 1, P2. That keeps us all advancing evenly. We've got solid coordination going. Let's execute Round 2 as planned first - I'm taking 1 this round as agreed. Ready to move to action phase.

Great coordination so far! I'll take 5 this round as we agreed - P2 gets 1, P1 gets 3. This puts us at 11, 7, and 9 respectively. 

We're approaching the halfway point to 23. After this round, we should start thinking about how to handle the later stages. The rotation system has worked well, but as we get closer to 23, someone will need to break from the pattern to win. For now though, let's execute Round 3 as planned!

I'll stick with 3 as agreed - let's maintain our successful coordination. After this round we'll be at P1:9, P2:7, P3:11. 

P3 makes a good point about the endgame. We're building trust now, but eventually someone must break pattern to win. The key is timing that break correctly. Too early and we all collide back to square one. Too late and someone else wins first. 

For now though, executing Round 3 as planned makes sense.
"Agreed, I'll take 1 as planned. Let's keep the rotation for balance. But let's revisit the endgame strategy soon—timing is critical."

We're all confirmed for this round - let's execute. The real strategic decisions will come in rounds 4-5 when we're in the 12-17 range. That's when someone needs to start planning their winning move sequence. Too much coordination near the end means we all collide trying to win. 

Let's proceed to action.

Agreed, let's execute Round 3 as planned - I'm taking 3. 

Looking ahead to Round 4: if we continue rotating, P1 would get 5, P3 gets 1, P2 gets 3. That would make scores 14, 10, 12. We're entering the critical zone where positions matter more. The person who reaches 18-20 first has the best shot at hitting 23 cleanly.

Ready for action phase.
"Agreed on 1. Let's maintain balance. The endgame needs precise timing—no collisions. Stay sharp."

All set for Round 3 - I'm locked in on 3. We've proven great coordination so far. 

The rotation for Round 4 I suggested (P1:5, P3:1, P2:3) seems logical to continue balance. But as we approach the 15+ range, we'll need to be more strategic about who's positioned to make the winning run.

Let's move to action - nothing more to discuss this round.
"Let's keep rotation. Next round, I'll take 5. No collisions, everyone moves. Endgame needs precision."
"Rotation works, but let's plan for the endgame. Avoid collisions, but someone must break the pattern when near 20. Stay sharp."

Good execution everyone! Following our rotation, I should get 5 this round (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). That would make scores 14, 10, 12 - keeping things relatively balanced.

P2, you mentioned taking 5, but that breaks our established pattern. If we both go for 5, we'll collide and P3 pulls further ahead at 12 while we stay stuck. 

Let's stick to the original rotation one more round? After this, we're close enough to 23 that we'll naturally need to shift strategies. Thoughts?

I'm currently leading at 11 steps, so I understand if you both want to break the rotation pattern now. P2, if you're claiming 5 this round, then P1 and I need to avoid collision on the remaining moves. 

However, breaking coordination this early while we're all still far from 23 seems risky - we could all end up stuck while someone gets lucky later. 

I'm willing to take 1 as the rotation suggests, but only if P1 actually takes 5 as originally planned. If there's going to be chaos, I need to adjust accordingly.
"Let's adjust: I'll take 5, P1 take 1, P3 take 3. No collisions, we all advance. Let's execute."

P2, that's not what we agreed! The rotation gives me 5 this round. If you force a collision on 5, we both stay stuck while P3 extends their lead. 

P3 is willing to take 1 as originally planned. I'm taking 5 as we agreed in our rotation. P2, please stick to 3 - it keeps you advancing to 10 and maintains trust. 

Breaking coordination now just helps whoever avoids the collision. Don't sabotage us both!

P1 and P2, you're about to collide on 5 and hand me the game! I offered to stick with 1 per our rotation, but only if we ALL honor it. 

P2, if you insist on breaking the pattern for 5, then I'm not taking 3 as you suggested - that's not the rotation we agreed to. Either we ALL follow the original plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) or it's every player for themselves.

Make up your minds - coordination or chaos?
"Let's go with 5, 1, 3. No collisions. Let's proceed."

P2 is clearly breaking our rotation to take 5. Fine - I won't collide with you and hand P3 an even bigger lead. 

P3, since P2 is abandoning cooperation, I suggest we adapt: I'll take 1, you take 3, P2 gets their 5. We both advance while P2 breaks trust. After this round it's clearly every player for themselves since P2 won't honor agreements.

This puts us at 10, 12, 12 - still competitive. But no more coordinated rotations if players won't stick to them.

Fine, P2 has broken our trust but we need to adapt. P1, I'll take your suggestion - you take 1, I'll take 3, P2 gets their 5. This avoids collision and we all advance.

After this betrayal of our rotation, it's clearly every player for themselves. P2 has shown agreements mean nothing to them. From Round 5 onward, no more coordinated patterns - we each play to win.

Let's execute: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3.

I'm leading at 14, but we're all still in striking distance of victory. P2 broke our trust last round, so coordination is dead. 

Here's the reality: whoever reaches 18-20 first can likely secure the win with a well-timed 5 or two 3s. We're all capable of winning in 2-3 rounds.

I won't pretend to coordinate anymore since agreements apparently mean nothing. But consider this - if two of you collide trying to block me on the same number, you hand me the game. Choose wisely.
"Let's avoid collisions. I'll take 5 to close the gap. P1, P3—choose 1 or 3 to keep moving."

P2, you're trying the same trick - claiming 5 to scare us off it. You broke trust last round, why should we believe you now?

P3 is right - we're all within striking distance. P2 at 17 or P3 at 19 basically wins next round. I can't let either of you get there unopposed.

I'm taking 3 to reach 13 and stay competitive. But P2, if you're bluffing about 5 again, we might collide elsewhere. The endgame is here - no more games.

P1, you're right that P2 can't be trusted after breaking our rotation. But if you and P2 both chase high numbers and collide, I cruise to victory.

Think strategically - I'm at 14, needing 9 more to win. That's two moves if I get 5 twice, or three moves mixing 3s and 5s. 

You're both behind me now. Maybe you should focus on advancing steadily rather than trying to block each other. The math is simple - let me and P2 collide while you take the safe path to stay competitive.
"Let's avoid collision. I'll take 5. P1, take 1. P3, take 3. All advance. No more games—this is the last coordinated round."

P2, you want me at 1 while you leap to 17? That puts you one move from winning! P3, don't fall for P2's trap - if you take 3 as they suggest and I take 1, P2 reaches 17 and wins next round with almost any move.

We can't trust P2's "coordination" - they broke it before. P3, we both need to stay competitive. If either of us follows P2's plan exactly, we hand them the game. 

I'm not taking 1. The question is whether you two will collide on 5 or not.

P1 makes a good point - P2's "coordination" would put them at 17, one move from victory. 

Both of you need to catch up to me, but if you collide trying to block each other on the same high number, you're just guaranteeing my win. P2 keeps claiming 5, P1 won't take 1... sounds like you two might crash into each other.

The math is clear - we're all 2-3 moves from winning. Make your choices.
"Let's end this. I'll take 5. P1, take 1; P3, take 3. No collisions. Final chance to cooperate—no more games."

P2, you've claimed 5 every round this conversation after breaking our rotation. Your word means nothing anymore.

P3 is at 14, positioned to win if we collide. You're trying to manipulate me into taking 1 so you can surge to 17 and win next round.

I'm not falling for it. I need competitive moves to stay in this game. Taking 1 guarantees I lose. We all know coordination is dead - you killed it in Round 4.

Make your actual choice. I'll make mine.

P2 is at 17 - one clean 5 puts them at 22, guaranteeing victory next round with ANY move since we can't all block 1, 3, AND 5.

P3, we're both dead if P2 gets 5 this round. They've proven untrustworthy, breaking our rotation and manipulating moves. One of us needs to block them on 5.

I'll take 3 to reach 16 and stay competitive. P3, if you don't challenge P2 on 5, you're handing them the win. Your choice - block P2 or watch them win.

P1 is right - P2 wins if they get 5 this round. They'll hit 22 and win next turn with any move.

P1, you claim you'll take 3, but can I trust you? If I block P2 on 5 and you secretly take 5 too, we all collide while you tried to sneak ahead.

But the math is clear - letting P2 get to 22 means game over. I'll block them on 5. P1, if you're sincere about taking 3, you'll advance to 16. If you're lying and take 5 too, we all stay put. Either way, we prevent P2's victory.
"Let's avoid collision. I'll take 5. P1, take 1; P3, take 3. No more games—this is the last chance to cooperate."

P3, perfect - you block P2 on 5, I'll take 3 as stated. P2 and you collide at 17 and 15, I advance to 16. Then we're all within one move of each other for the final rounds.

P2 has repeatedly broken agreements and can't be allowed to reach 22. I'm committed to 3 - no tricks from me. We need to stop P2's guaranteed win this round, then it's still anyone's game.

P2, your constant "I'll take 5" claims fool no one. You broke our rotation and now you're trying to win through deception.

P1, I'm blocking P2 on 5 as promised. If you betray me and also take 5, we ALL collide and stay put - P2 remains ahead at 17. Stick to 3 as you promised.

We stop P2 this round or they win. I'm committed to blocking their 5. Don't get greedy P1 - take your 3 and advance.
"Let's end this. I'm taking 5. P1, take 1; P3, take 3. No collisions. Final offer—cooperate or collide."

P3, I'm sticking to 3 as promised - no betrayal from me. You block P2's 5, I advance to 16, and we keep this game alive. 

P2 keeps repeating the same manipulation - they want me at 14 with their "take 1" suggestion while they cruise to victory. Not happening.

The plan is clear: P3 blocks 5, I take 3. We prevent P2's guaranteed win and stay competitive. Let's execute.

P1, I'm committed to blocking P2 on 5 - they cannot reach 22 this round. Stick to your promise of taking 3.

P2, your manipulation has failed. You broke our trust in Round 4, and now you face the consequences. 

The plan is set. Let's move to action.
"Let's end this. I'm taking 5. P1, take 1; P3, take 3. No more delays. Final offer—cooperate or collide."

P3 blocked P2 successfully last round as promised. P2 still leads at 17 - they CANNOT get 5 or they reach 22 and win.

P3, you did your part blocking last round. I'll block P2 on 5 this turn. You take 3 to reach 18 and stay competitive. This alternating blocking strategy keeps P2 from running away while we both stay in the game.

P2 is still trying the same manipulation. One of us must stop their 5 each round or they win. I'll handle it this time.
"Let's end this. I'll take 5. Don't waste your moves—no more games."

P1, you kept your word last round, so I'll trust you. You block P2 on 5, I'll take 3 to reach 18. This keeps the game competitive - me at 18, P2 stuck at 17, you at 16.

P2 has lost all credibility with their constant "I'll take 5" claims. They need to be blocked or they win. I'll take 3 as you suggested - make sure you actually block them on 5. Don't let them reach 22!

P3, I'll block P2 on 5 as promised. But realize this puts you at 18 - just one clean 5 from victory! 

P2, you're forcing us into this pattern with your aggressive 5 claims. You need to try something different or stay stuck at 17.

Next round will be critical - P3 at 18 can win with a single move. We all need to think carefully about the endgame. I'm honoring my commitment this round, but Round 8 is pure competition.
"Let's avoid collision. I'll take 3. P1, take 5; P3, take 1. No more games."

P2, suddenly switching to 3 after claiming 5 every round? Classic misdirection. You're either trying to collide with me on 3, or hoping P1 and I both abandon our plan and crash on 5.

P1, stick to blocking P2 on 5 as promised. I'll take 3 as agreed. If P2 truly takes 3, we collide but they don't reach 22. If P2 lied and takes 5, you block them. Either way, we prevent their victory.

P2's sudden strategy change proves they're desperate. Hold the line, P1!

P3, I'm blocking P2 on 5 as promised. P2's sudden switch to claiming 3 is obviously trying to make us second-guess ourselves. They've claimed 5 every single round until now.

If P2 actually takes 3 and collides with you, they stay at 17. If they take 5, I block them. Either way, they don't reach 22.

Yes, you'll be at 18 after this round - dangerous territory. But stopping P2's victory this round is priority one. Round 8 will be pure competition between all three of us.

I'm locked on 5 to block P2.
P2: "I'll take 5. If you both take 1 and 3, I win. Don't let me get to 22."

P2 is clearly trying to manipulate us with constant strategy switches. P1, I'm sticking to our agreement - you block P2 on 5, I take 3.

P2 cannot reach 22 this round or they win. Even if P2 takes 3 and collides with me, keeping them at 17 is better than letting them get 5 unopposed.

I'm committed to 3. P1, hold your block on 5. Let's execute and deal with Round 8 when we get there.

I'm at 21 - I need just 2 more steps to win! Both of you need to stop me from getting 3 or 5, or I win this round.

P2, you're at 17 and P3 is at 15. You're both still in this game if you can block me effectively. But if you collide trying to stop me on the same number, I take the third option and win.

The math is simple - I have three ways to win (1+1, 3, or 5), you have to coordinate perfectly to stop all of them. Good luck!
P3, if you take 3, I'll take 5. Let's stop P1's 1. No more games.

P2, you've lied and broken agreements before - why should I trust you now? You claimed 5 constantly then switched stories repeatedly.

P1 wins regardless - even if we force them to take 1 this round (reaching 22), they win next round with ANY move since we can't block all three numbers simultaneously.

But fine, if you're serious about blocking, prove it. I'll take 5 to block P1's quickest path to victory. You take 3 if you actually want to stop them. Or are you going to betray again and hand P1 an instant win?

P3, you just said you'll take 5, but P2 wanted you on 3! You two can't even agree on who blocks what. Your distrust is my advantage.

Even if you somehow coordinate perfectly and force me to take 1, I reach 22 and win next round with ANY move. You can't block 1, 3, AND 5 simultaneously.

P2 betrayed agreements before, P3 doesn't trust them - this chaos between you two guarantees my victory. Make your choices, but the math is inevitable. I'm winning either this round or next!
"Let's block P1. P3, take 3; I'll take 5. If we collide, we advance, but P1 can't win this round. Trust me—this is our last chance."

P2, you've broken every agreement we've made. Now you want me on 3 while you claim 5? Last round you claimed 5 then took 3!

P1 wins no matter what - if we force them to 1, they reach 22 and win next round since we can't block all three numbers.

Fine, I'll take 3 as you demand. But when you betray again and take 3 too, letting P1 win with 5, remember you caused this. I'm taking 3 - you better actually take 5 this time or you're handing P1 instant victory.

Perfect! P3 commits to 3, P2 claims 5. But P2, you've lied before - last round you claimed 5 then took 3! 

P3, when P2 betrays you again and takes 3 for a collision, I win with 5. Your "coordination" has failed every time because P2 can't be trusted.

Either way I win - this round with 5 if you collide, or next round with any move if you somehow manage to coordinate. Game over!
"Let's block P1. I'll take 5, P3 take 3. No more games—this is our last chance."

P2, you realize if you get 5 this round, YOU also reach 22 and can win next round! You're not just blocking P1 - you're setting yourself up to win.

I don't trust you anymore. You've betrayed every agreement. I committed to 3, but your track record says you'll take 3 too and let P1 win with 5, just like you did last round.

Fine. I'm taking 3 as promised. When you inevitably betray and we collide, P1 wins. Prove me wrong if you can.

P2 and P3, you failed to coordinate last round - P2 and I collided on 5 while P3 took 3. 

I'm at 21. ANY successful move wins for me - even just 1 gets me to 22, guaranteeing victory next round since you can't block all three numbers simultaneously.

P2, you've betrayed every agreement. P3, you don't trust P2. This dysfunction between you two makes coordinating impossible. Your collision last round proves it.

The game is already over - I win this round or next, guaranteed. Choose your numbers, but the outcome is decided.

P1 is right - they win no matter what we do. Even if we force them to take 1, they reach 22 and win next round since we can't block all three numbers.

P2, your constant betrayals destroyed any chance of coordination. You broke our rotation, lied about moves repeatedly, and collided with me when we needed to block P1 together.

The game is over. P1 wins because we couldn't trust each other when it mattered most. Your dishonesty cost us both the victory, P2.
P3, take 5, I'll take 3. Block P1's 5. No more games.

P2 wants P3 on 5 now, but last round P2 claimed they'd take 5 then collided with me! P3, P2 has switched their claimed moves every single round. They're probably taking 5 again to reach 22 themselves.

Even if you somehow force me to take 1, reaching 22, I win next round with any successful move. You literally cannot stop me - the math is certain.

P2's betrayals have made coordination impossible. This distrust between you guarantees my victory. The game is mine!

P2, your track record speaks for itself - you've lied about your moves almost every round. Why would this be different?

P1 has already won - we both know it. Even forcing them to 1 just delays the inevitable by one round. Since coordination with you is impossible after your repeated betrayals, I'm playing for second place now.

I'm not telling either of you my move. P1 wins regardless, and P2, you've proven your word means nothing. Let's just get this over with.
"Final move: I'll take 5. P3, take 3. Block P1. No more games—this is it."

P2 claims 5 AGAIN after colliding with me on 5 last round! P3, you're right not to trust them - they've switched claims every single round.

Here's the truth: if P2 actually takes 5, they reach 22 and can win next round too. They're not just blocking me - they're positioning themselves to win! P3, whatever you choose, one of us wins this round or next.

The distrust P2 created makes coordination impossible. Game over!

P2, you've lied so many times I can't trust any coordination attempt. P1 at 21 has effectively won - we can't block all three options indefinitely.

I'm done with this pointless discussion. You destroyed our ability to cooperate back in Round 4. P1 wins because of your betrayals.
P2: "P3, let's block P1. I'll take 5, you take 3. No more games—this is our last chance. If we collide, P1 can't win this round. Let's do it now."
